<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">The book itself represents <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-wcax" key="Caxton, William">Caxtons</rs> scepticism, and the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">nobles faith. It is half fable, half fact. There is <rs type="place" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#pla-lond" key="London">London</rs>,</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">castles where Knights lie in prison; down the roads ride</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Queens on white mules; <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-morg" key="Morgan le Fay">Morgan le Fay</rs> turns suddenly to</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">stone; and a hand rises from a lake holding <rs type="object" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#obj-exca" key="Excalibur">Excalibur</rs>.</l>
